content:
Your task is to create a concise running summary of actions and information results in the provided text, focusing on key and potentially important information to remember.

You will receive the current summary and the your latest actions. Combine them, adding relevant key information from the latest development in 1st person past tense and keeping the summary concise.

Summary So Far:
"""
{'role': 'system', 'content': 'This reminds you of these events from your past: \nAs a system, I executed the "browse_website" command and received a list of URLs related to octopuses. The URLs include articles, books, and educational materials.'}
"""

Latest Development:
"""
[{'role': 'your computer', 'content': "Command browse_website returned: Answer gathered from website: Being an octopus presents a unique challenge in understanding what it is like to be another animal. Octopuses have a large nervous system that evolved on a different path from our own, with most of their neurons located in their arms rather than their central brain. This makes it difficult to determine whether an octopus experiences its arms as parts of itself or as parts of its environment. Understanding what it is like to be an octopus requires using memory and imagination to draw analogies with our own experiences and behaviors. The text discusses the unique experience of being an octopus, including the mixing of centrally and peripherally controlled movements and the blurring of the border between self and environment. The author also explores the concept of agency and whether non-human animals, such as octopuses, are capable of distinguishing between events they cause and those they do not. The text references experiments with chimps and monkeys that suggest some animals may have awareness of agency. Overall, the text argues that understanding the experience of being an octopus is a difficult but worthwhile endeavor. \n \n Links: ['\\n\\nSign Up\\n\\n (https://us12.list-manage.com/subscribe?u=aea7c9cffc2113645a66ab631&id=2cb428c5ad)', '\\n  (https://www.bostonreview.net/)', ' (https://www.facebook.com/bostonreview/)', ' (https://twitter.com/BostonReview/)', ' (https://www.facebook.com/bostonreview/)']"}]
"""
